Award.AwardTitle: High-Resolution Electrical Sensing of Surface Charges and Currents of Living Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research project is to perform high-resolution sensing of surface charges and ionic currents of living cells. Both these measurements will provide important information about the cell membrane and underlying proteins. Understanding the pivotal role of membrane proteins in clinical diagnostics requires measurement tools with high-resolution and distributed sensing. Thus, this project is motivated by the need to miniaturize bioassays with higher resolution and the present lack of integrated measurement tools for advanced cellular studies. The following research tasks will be undertaken (i) electronic sensors to monitor vesicle trafficking and intercellular communication electronically and at real-time, (ii) electrophysiology sites to simultaneously record ionic currents in parallel, (iii) ultra low-noise amplifier with correlated-double-sampling (CDS) sensitive signal readout to process ionic currents, and (iv) a new hybrid approach to model physiological changes within a single ion-channel, cell or cellular assembly.

The integrated system will provide an unprecedented level of spatial and temporal resolution for cellular studies. The integrated education and out-reach components proposed investigation are expected to greatly improve the representation of female students in electrical engineering and open avenues of biotechnology research for engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project developed an electronic platform to measure electrical signals from living cells. In general, membranes of living cells have ion channels that regulate the flow of ions through the cell. In addition, surface charges on the cell membrane can be measured by capacitive techniques. In this project, we designed an electronic chip with multiple devices; each device capable of measuring surface charges. The devices were fabricated by an outside foundry (MOSIS) and tested with a range of chemical solutions. The threshold voltage of the devices altered depending on the amount of surface charges on the electronic chip. Later, we tested suitable coating chemicals to be put on the electronic chip that promoted cell adhesion. A series of trials were conducted to compare different coating chemistries that promoted cell viability and growth on electronic chips. Neuronal cell lines were cultured on the electronic chips and we saw viable cells over a period of five days. An electronic circuit-board was built to remotely read or trigger the multiple devices on the electronic chip during cell culture experiments. The project helped train students in cell culture and wet chemistry, besides their education in engineering. One Ph.D. student and one M.S. student worked on this project and graduated with their thesis on this subject. The M.S. student received a NSF Graduate Fellowship and is pursuing his research interests on Brain Chip technologies at a top ranked university. One peer-reviewed journal publication in IEEE Sensors was published and two best student poster awards were received by students working on this project.
